awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Monitoring trees for water stress via a smart sensing system
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a sensing system that may provide invaluable and continuous insights into tree health and forest function at both large and small scales.  The market for this device will range from individual to industrial scale farmers wishing to tailor automated irrigation systems directly to address when trees (e.g., all varieties of tree nuts, avocado, coffee, fruits, etc.) experience stress or require specific moisture conditions to stimulate flowering or fruiting.  Other users may include governments and non-government organizations (NGOs) seeking to manage forested regions to assess the potential for wildfire ignition and spread, as well as scientific instrumentation companies who supply researchers seeking to understand forest responses to climate and disturbances. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a smart-sensing system for the detection of water stress in trees in response to local microclimates. Trees experience water stress at different intensities and time scales that may often be decoupled from soil moisture status. The proposed smart sensing system combines standard meteorological observations with novel measurements of within-tree water flow and content. This system features a tree-water content sensor capable of continuously monitoring water within different layers of a tree’s xylem tissues. Prior field research has shown that xylem tissues that are no longer actively transporting water may still serve as a water reservoir during times of drought for some species. Observations of tree water storage have shown promise in their ability to pinpoint the onset of water stress within a living plant in real time. In addition, data collected by this sensing system may be combined with remote sensing observations to extend predictions from single trees or orchards to entire regions to develop predictions for wildfire ignition potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this NSF iCorps project, we assessed the market demand and developed a business model for a novel smart-sensing system to detect water stress in trees. Trees experience water stress at different intensities and time scales impacting tree function and potential mortality. For instance, trees have the highest water content just before dawn after recharging their hydraulic system overnight, and the lowest water content in mid-afternoon after a full day of losing water to transpiration, regardless of soil water availability. On longer time scales, trees experience water stress progressively as soil water declines between watering periods or rainfall events. Tree-water dynamics are further complicated by the variety of water use strategies employed by each species to dynamically regulate water uptake and loss in response to changing soil and weather conditions. In fact, many species' water use becomes decoupled from shallow soil moisture observations, common in most agricultural and silvicultural applications, during cases of low soil moisture. Therefore, our smart sensing system combines standard meteorological observations (i.e. temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, rainfall, and shallow soil moisture) with novel observations of tree-water flow and content. This sensing system demonstrates Intellectual Merit by allowing simultaneous observations of water storage and transport within the xylem of mature, living trees in conjunction with a full suite of meteorological measurements. This technology allows us to observe when trees begin to reduce photosynthesis and water use in the face of stress, and how long recovery takes after water stress is alleviated. These data can be combined with remote sensing observations to extend predictions from single trees or orchards to entire regions to create predictions for wildfire ignition potential. Our sensing system provides invaluable and continuous insights into tree health and function at both large and small scales.

Through this iCorps project we conducted one hundred and ten customer discovery interviews and tested forty-seven hypotheses regarding our potential business model. The market for this device ranges from farmers wishing to tailor automated irrigation systems directly to address when trees (e.g. all varieties of tree nuts, avocado, coffee, fruits, etc.) experience stress or require specific moisture conditions to stimulate flowering or fruiting, to governments and NGOs seeking to manage forested regions to assess the potential for wildfire ignition and spread. When assessing vegetation moisture to address potential wildfire fuel loads, this sensing system allows land managers to understand when conditions favor controlled burns (e.g. high canopy moisture with dry understory) versus dangerous canopy fires (e.g. low canopy moisture with dry understory). Data gathered from these systems can enable managers to better understand fire risk and make more informed decisions regarding the timing and extent of management best practices. Simultaneously, data gathered by these systems in agricultural applications enables more precise irrigation practices which reduce the cost of irrigation for farmers while also reducing demand on already overtaxed water resources and reservoirs. The precise understanding of when the onset of stress occurs will help scientist, farmers, managers, and modelers better address the resilience of global forests and crops in the face of an increasingly variable climate.

During our customer discovery efforts, we also learned that the majority of potential customers who would be interest in this product would be willing to contribute any and all data collected by the product for open-source scientific research benefitting the agricultural and hydrological communities as a whole! Based on the customer interviews, we were able to outline the next steps for our LEAF logger system, before it is truly marketable. Therefore, we are actively designing a user-friendly system interface, online data portal, documentation, and user support guidelines to help non-expert users operate the system. To reach our desired minimum viable product, we are continuing to test the newest versions of our LEAF system in partnership with stakeholders including the City of Austin (Texas) and the Austin Fire Department to ensure that our product aligns with customer expectations of a plug-and-play system with a range of pre-selected sensor system configurations designed to meet the needs of each different customer segment.
